results.title: The Roman wall
results.brief_description: Historical film illustrating life in Britain during the Roman occupations and dealing, in particular, with Hadrian’s Wall, its construction and use as a defence against northern tribes. Shows the extent of the Roman Empire at the time of Hadrian, the significance of the Wall in relation to the Empire; construction of the defensive wall; the Roman method of defence and attack; details of buildings in which the soldiers lived and worked; military roads providing communications along the wall and with Roman Britain; the Wall as it is today.

results.title: The Rolling rice ball: a Japanese fairytale
results.brief_description: In charming animation, the film tells the story of the Japanese woodcutter who drops his luncheon rice balls in a mouse hole, then follows them down. The delightful mice show their appreciation by presenting him with costly presents to take home to his wife. A greedy hunter learns of the mice’s treasure and seeks it for himself. However, he frightens the mice, gets the treasure and learns the folly of greed.

results.title: The Roll press: a Hugh Smith shipyard machine tool
results.brief_description: Documentary explaining the significance of the roll press introduced by Hugh Smith in the early 1900s. Talks of the technical aspects of how it’s built plus its use and significance to the shipyard.

results.title: The Roll of drums
results.brief_description: A circus performer is trained to take calculated risks, he plans, practises and perfects the stunts, for which he gets paid. Often users of heavy machinery take risks which lead to serious accidents. When danger is at hand, the victim should hear a roll of drums and take evasive action.

results.title: The Role of government in the Australian economy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
Richard Bluck examines the role of the Australian Government in formulating economic policies. Discusses the Australian Public Sector, the market system, market capitalism, the Great Debate and other recent Australian experiences.

results.title: The Role of government
results.creator_credit: David Jackson, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Legislation is one of the ways by which tight control is kept on environmental matters relating to public health. Looks at the way such legislation arises, how it is drafted within a Government department and the political constraints on its implementation.

results.title: The Rocky horror picture show. - [Collector's ed.]
results.creator_credit: Jim Sharman, Michael White and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A cult classic, “The Rocky Horror Picture Show” has it all. A musical score by Richard O’Brien, who also stars as the butler Riff Raff, high energy dancing and excellent performances by Barry Bostwick and Susan Sarandon as preppie couple Brad and Janet; Tim Curry as Doctor Frank’n’furter, the ‘Sweet transvestite from transsexual Transylvania’, and a host of others. This collector’s edition celebrates the film’s 21st birthday and includes an hour of extra footage of deleted scenes, outtakes and the Rocky Horror phenomena.

results.title: The Rock
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and World Mirror
results.brief_description: A travelogue of Gibraltar. The atmosphere of cosmopolitan bustle in the busy streets and cafes; the holidaymakers on the sunlit beaches; the mixed uniforms of soldiers, sailors and airmen stationed at “Gib”; the famous Barbary Apes; the Ceremony of the Keys in the fortress.

results.title: The Robot moles
results.creator_credit: Tadanori Okamoto, Masaji Hara, Matsue Jimbo and Gakken Company
results.brief_description: Japanese animated puppet film. Hanako, a little girl who loves flowers, makes a drawing of a mechanical mole which would cultivate flowers. The scientists mistake it for an order to construct such a device, and build a team of robot moles.

results.title: The Robin Klein video
results.creator_credit: Mike Waters, Christine McCaul Gleitzman and Insight Profile
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Insight profile”.
Celebrated children’s author Robin Klein discusses her lifelong passion with creative writing and the ideas process that never stops. In particular, she talks about the importance of “mooning about,” and the mooning and locales that have provided the source of inspiration behind “Halfway across the galaxy and turn left”, “Hating Alison Ashley” and the Penny Pollard series. The program provides practical examples of observations that can be made from everyday encounters, such as at an historic railway station or spending time round a school. She speaks of her own personal style of writing, the first draft, the importance of self discipline, tools of the trade and the importance of the editorial process. Robin’s books are enjoyed by children of all ages and have been adapted for stage and screen.
